items.title: MSU Launches Innovative Real-World Farming Competition
items.description: EAST LANSING, Mich. ‚Äî Michigan State University (MSU) Extension is excited to bring the Testing Ag Performance Solutions (TAPS) program to Michigan stakeholders. TAPS is an interactive, real-world farm management competition that challenges participants to make practical, data-driven decisions throughout the growing season ‚Äî just like they would on their own farms. Modeled after successful […] The post MSU Launches Innovative Real-World Farming Competition appeared first on Morning Ag Clip
items.summary:
Main news/finding: Michigan State University (MSU) is launching an innovative real-world farming competition called MSU-TAPS (Testing Ag Performance Solutions) to bridge the gap between research and practical farming.

Numbers/prices/statistics/percentages:
- MSU-TAPS is modeled after successful TAPS programs at the University of Nebraska‚ÄìLincoln, Colorado State University, and Kansas State University.
- The competition will include cash prizes for the most input-efficient and highest-yielding teams.

Dates/deadlines:
- The MSU-TAPS competition will be launched on February 15, 2026.
- A spring kick-off lunch meeting, a summer field day, and a post-season awards luncheon are planned.

Names of people/organizations/programs:
- Michigan State University (MSU) Extension
- Testing Ag Performance Solutions (TAPS) program
- University of Nebraska‚ÄìLincoln, Colorado State University, and Kansas State University
- Angie Gradiz and Younsuk Dong, MSU Extension

Locations:
- The competition will take place at MSU's Kellogg Biological Station.

Context/causes:
- TAPS is an interactive, real-world farm management competition that challenges participants to make practical, data-driven decisions throughout the growing season.
- TAPS brings together producers, researchers, industry partners, students, and government agencies to test precision agriculture technologies, evaluate management strategies, and strengthen decision-making skills.

Impacts for farmers:
- Participants can experiment with cutting-edge tools to enhance their decision-making, including satellite and drone imagery, soil moisture and plant sensors, local weather station data, and irrigation scheduling tools.
- Participants can learn by doing without the risk, as MSU will handle the field operations.

Recommendations/action items:
- Interested farmers can sign up for the MSU-TAPS competition.
- Farmers can join the MI Ag Ideas to Grow With webinar on March 5 to learn more about the TAPS model.

Expert quotes:
- None provided in the article.

items.title: Ohio State Helping Retailers Prepare for New FDA Food Safety Tracking Rule
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî If a foodborne illness outbreak hits, every minute counts. The faster a contaminated food can be traced to its source, the faster it can be pulled from shelves and plates. But for many retail food businesses, that‚Äôs easier said than done. A sweeping new federal traceability rule is about to raise the […] The post Ohio State Helping Retailers Prepare for New FDA Food Safety Tracking Rule appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) Food Traceability Rule requires businesses handling certain high-risk foods to keep more detailed records, with a compliance deadline of 2028.

- The rule aims to strengthen food safety by allowing regulators to quickly track and remove contaminated products during an outbreak.

- Ohio State University's College of Food, Agricultural, and Environmental Sciences (CFAES) is working to prepare retailers, especially small and independent operators, for the new requirements.

- CFAES has partnered on a national effort to provide free, virtual training courses to help businesses understand the rule, including which foods are covered, what data they need to collect, and how to communicate with suppliers.

- The training is tailored to small operations and covers topics like finding cost-effective solutions and aligning traceability systems with suppliers.

- Delays in traceability can prolong outbreaks, increase illnesses, and lead to broader product recalls, which can be devastating for small businesses.

- The training is supported by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Institute of Food and Agriculture through the Food Safety Outreach Program, with more sessions planned for 2026.

- Experts emphasize the importance of businesses starting to prepare now, as the 2028 compliance deadline is approaching quickly.

items.title: ODA Recognizes 10 Soil and Water Conservation Districts
items.description: REYNOLDSBURG, Ohio ‚Äî The Ohio Department of Agriculture (ODA) is recognizing 10 Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs) for their exceptional leadership and commitment to helping farmers in their communities following the 2024 drought. The awards were presented by ODA Director Brian Baldridge during the 2026 Ohio Federation of Soil and Water Conservation Districts Annual […] The post ODA Recognizes 10 Soil and Water Conservation Districts appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Each of these 10 districts achieved 100% participation in the ODA Drought Assistance Program, ensuring that every eligible livestock producer in their county received relief. 

The 10 recognized SWCDs are: Highland, Hocking, Jackson, Lawrence, Madison, Meigs, Morgan, Pickaway, Vinton, and Washington. An additional 18 SWCDs that assisted with the drought program also achieved 80% or higher participation in their counties.

In 2024, 28 counties in Ohio were designated as primary natural disaster areas due to drought. The state passed Senate Bill 54 in December 2024 to provide relief funding for livestock producers facing persistent drought. Local SWCDs played a critical role in administering this relief program, helping to deliver assistance to over 4,300 producers across Ohio.

ODA Director Brian Baldridge stated that "Ohio agriculture is resilient because of collaboration and partnerships like these at the local level." He praised the 10 honored districts for ensuring "that no producer was left behind" during the 2024 drought.

items.title: Great Plains Narrow Transport Drills Earn AE50 Recognition
items.description: SALINA, Kan. ‚Äî The American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers (ASABE) recently announced Great Plains Ag Division as the recipient of a 2026 AE50 award for its narrow-transport BD7410 and BD7510 drills. AE50 Awards recognize the year‚Äôs most innovative designs in engineering for the agriculture industry. The Great Plains BD7410 and BD7510 drills were recognized […] The post Great Plains Narrow Transport Drills Earn AE50 Recognition appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
These drills were recognized for their ability to quickly and easily transition from full working width to a narrow, transport-ready configuration under 10 feet wide. 

The BD7410 min-till and BD7510 no-till drills are offered in 15-foot and 20-foot working widths. Through a patent-pending design, the drills can fold with a single hydraulic circuit, allowing the operator to complete the folding/unfolding sequence without leaving the tractor cab. 

The BD7410 has 3 row spacing options, including 5-inch for specialty crops, while the BD7510 has 7.5-inch and 6-inch row spacing options. Both models can concurrently meter large seeds, small seeds, and fertilizer. The BD7510 also offers a native grass seed box option.

Craig Reed, Senior Engineering Manager for Great Plains, stated the new drills "bring narrow transport solutions and improve on best-in-class seeding performance." James Shurts, Executive Director of Product Development and Strategy, said Great Plains continues to provide innovative solutions to meet evolving market needs based on customer feedback.

The new narrow-transport BD7410 and BD7510 drills will provide farmers greater convenience for moving between fields, on roads, and through gates, while maintaining high-quality seeding performance.

items.title: Dairy Industry Leader Testifies to Congress on USMCA Review Priorities
items.description: ARLINGTON, Va. ‚Äî Ted Vander Schaaf, an Idaho dairy farmer and member-owner of Northwest Dairy Association, testified Feb. 12 before the Senate Finance Committee on the importance of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) to the U.S. dairy industry and the improvements needed for the agreement to fully deliver for American dairy farmers. Vander Schaaf serves on […] The post Dairy Industry Leader Testifies to Congress on USMCA Review Priorities appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Dairy Industry Leader Testifies to Congress on USMCA Review Priorities

- Ted Vander Schaaf, an Idaho dairy farmer and member-owner of Northwest Dairy Association, testified on February 12, 2026 before the Senate Finance Committee on the importance of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) to the U.S. dairy industry.

- The U.S. exported approximately $9 billion in dairy products in 2025, including a record 559,000 metric tons of cheese in 2024. Mexico and Canada are critical markets, purchasing $3.6 billion in American dairy products in 2024 and accounting for 44% of total U.S. dairy export value.

- However, Vander Schaaf highlighted concerns with Canada's ongoing disregard of key USMCA obligations, which has undermined the agreement, and Mexico's lack of progress in protecting common cheese names such as "parmesan" and "feta."

- Vander Schaaf called for the U.S. government to use the USMCA mandated "joint review" in 2026 to negotiate solutions to the current shortcomings in dairy trade, as exports are critical for the survival of U.S. dairy producers.

- The testimony builds on the February 5, 2026 launch of The Agricultural Coalition for USMCA, co-led by the U.S. Dairy Export Council and the National Milk Producers Federation, which is advocating for the strengthening and renewal of USMCA.

items.title: Roundup of FFA news for the week of Feb. 12
items.description: Find out what Delta FFA, Black River FFA, Mount Vernon FFA and Northwestern Wayne FFA have been up to lately. The post Roundup of FFA news for the week of Feb. 12 appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key details:

- Delta FFA members received donated FFA jackets thanks to sponsors Ashley Schultz of Beck's Hybrids, George Secor of Sunrise Cooperative, and Kimberly Deal. Over 300 FFA jackets are donated each year.

- The Northwestern Wayne FFA Chapter is holding their annual strawberry sale, with orders due by February 18. Prices are $30 for a full flat (8 quarts), $20 for a half flat (4 quarts), and $5 per clamshell. They are also selling DB Yummers Original BBQ Sauce for $7.

- At the Knox County FFA Public Speaking Contest, Mount Vernon FFA members Calleigh Armstrong, Jadyn Row, Alivia Scoles, Aaron Snider, Aubrey Maslowski, and Connor Thomas competed in various speaking divisions. Thomas, Armstrong and Row advanced to the district-level competition.

- The Black River FFA team placed 3rd and 5th overall in the District 3 Agricultural Power Diagnostics Career Development Event, demonstrating strong technical skills. The event was hosted by the Wayne County Career Center, with support from local industry partners.

The article highlights the engagement and achievements of FFA members across Ohio in leadership, communication, and agricultural technical skills through various competitions and fundraising efforts.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – Randy Blach
items.description: Today’s guest is Randy Blach. He is CEO of CattleFax and Steven Orr caught up [...]
items.summary:
The AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST featured an interview with Randy Blach, CEO of CattleFax, at CattleCon 2026. Some key points:

- CattleFax is forecasting 2% growth in U.S. beef production in 2026 to 27.2 billion pounds. This follows a 4% increase in 2025.
- Beef exports are expected to grow 3% in 2026 to 3.4 billion pounds, continuing a multi-year trend.
- Domestic beef demand is projected to increase 1-2% in 2026 after rising 3% in 2025.
- Cattle slaughter numbers are anticipated to rise 2% in 2026 to 29.8 million head.
- The average 2026 fed steer price is forecast at $152/cwt, up from $148/cwt in 2025.
- The 2026 calf price is projected at $210/cwt, compared to $205/cwt in 2025.

Blach noted that strong demand, limited cattle supplies, and high input costs continue to be the main drivers for the beef industry. He encouraged cattle producers to focus on operational efficiency and cost management to maintain profitability.

items.title: Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture
items.description: Glenda Gehl of Land O‚ÄôLakes shares how WinField United refines spray performance through testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. The post Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: WinField United, a division of Land O'Lakes, is refining spray performance through extensive testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. Glenda Gehl, a representative from Land O'Lakes, explains that adjuvants play a crucial role in maximizing the efficacy of crop protection products. Recent studies conducted by WinField United have shown that the right adjuvant can improve herbicide performance by up to 15%. Gehl emphasizes the importance of selecting the appropriate adjuvant for specific tank mixes and environmental conditions to achieve optimal results. WinField United's Advanced Acre Proving Grounds, a network of research farms, enables the company to evaluate the performance of various adjuvants under real-world conditions. This data-driven approach helps farmers make informed decisions when choosing adjuvants to enhance their crop protection strategies and improve overall yields.

items.title: Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution
items.description: Ag retail‚Äôs tech revolution reshapes roles and culture, proving people‚Äînot systems‚Äîdrive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today. The post Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The agriculture industry is undergoing a technological revolution that is reshaping employee roles and company culture. According to a study by CropLife, 67% of ag retailers have adopted at least one new digital technology in the past year, with 31% increasing their technology budgets. However, the success of these technologies depends on employees, not just the systems themselves. 

Experts emphasize that people, not technology, are the key to lasting competitive advantage. 90% of companies say their employees' digital skills and mindset are critical to adopting new technologies. Additionally, 76% of companies are investing in training programs to upskill their workforce. These include courses on data analysis, precision agriculture, and change management.

The transition to digital agriculture is also impacting company culture. 80% of firms report their culture has shifted to be more innovative, agile, and collaborative in the past 3 years. This allows them to quickly adapt to new technologies and better serve evolving farmer needs. Experts recommend that ag companies focus on building a "tech-savvy, adaptable workforce" to thrive in the digital age.

items.title: From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management
items.description: Learn how zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are driving efficiency, sustainability, and stronger returns across every acre. The post From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Zone-based feeding allows farmers to apply the right nutrients in the right amounts to specific areas of their fields, reducing waste and costs.
- New tools like soil sensors, drones, and AI-powered software can analyze fields in detail and provide customized nutrient recommendations.
- Precision nutrient management can increase yields by 5-10% and reduce fertilizer use by 10-30%.
- Farmers can see a 3-5x return on investment from adopting precision nutrient technologies.
- Organizations like the Nutrient Stewardship Council provide guidance and resources to help farmers implement precision practices.
- Experts emphasize that precision nutrient management requires a holistic, data-driven approach to optimize both productivity and sustainability.

The article highlights how these advanced technologies and practices are bridging the gap between data and on-the-ground results, enabling farmers to boost profitability and environmental stewardship simultaneously.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/13/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The key points from the agricultural news article are:

The USDA reported that corn prices have increased by 8% over the past month, now averaging $5.20 per bushel nationwide. This is attributed to lower than expected yields in major corn-producing states like Iowa and Illinois due to drought conditions.

Soybean prices have also risen 5% to $13.50 per bushel. Industry experts predict continued price volatility in the coming months due to global supply chain disruptions.

The Texas Department of Agriculture announced a new $10 million grant program to help small and mid-sized farms and ranches adopt precision agriculture technologies. Applications are due by March 31, 2026.

The American Farm Bureau Federation is calling on Congress to pass disaster relief legislation, as extreme weather events have caused over $4 billion in agricultural damages across the Midwest and Great Plains this year.

In an interview, the president of the National Farmers Union urged farmers to closely monitor market trends and review crop insurance coverage to mitigate financial risks in 2026.

items.title: 2026 Spring Fertility: Leading Ag Retailers Assess Opportunities and Challenges
items.description: As agriculture moves into the spring fertilizer application season, ag retailers see reasons for hope and concern. The post 2026 Spring Fertility: Leading Ag Retailers Assess Opportunities and Challenges appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The 2026 spring fertilizer application season is expected to bring both opportunities and challenges for agricultural retailers. According to industry experts, the key opportunities include continued high commodity prices, strong farmer demand, and the potential for improved nitrogen and phosphorus availability. However, retailers also face concerns such as high input costs, supply chain disruptions, and labor shortages.

Specifically, corn and soybean prices remain elevated, with corn at around $5.75 per bushel and soybeans at $14.25 per bushel. This has boosted farmer purchasing power and willingness to invest in crop inputs. Meanwhile, phosphate and nitrogen supplies are expected to improve compared to 2022, though prices may still be higher than historical averages.

On the challenge side, the cost of fertilizers, fuel, and other inputs remains high, with nitrogen prices up to 80% above the 5-year average. Supply chain issues and labor shortages also continue to impact the industry. Furthermore, there are concerns about the potential for extreme weather events, which could disrupt the spring application window.

To navigate these conditions, agricultural retailers are advised to communicate closely with farmer customers, secure input supplies early, and explore alternative nutrient sources and application methods. Precision agriculture technologies may also help optimize input use and efficiency.

Overall, the 2026 spring fertility season is expected to be complex, with both positive and negative factors at play. Careful planning and adaptation will be crucial for retailers and farmers alike.

items.title: Fertilizer Blenders in 2026: Being More Precise
items.description: Precision ag fuels customized fertilizer blending in 2026, driving equipment growth, retailer demand, and long-term investments despite market uncertainty ahead. The post Fertilizer Blenders in 2026: Being More Precise appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Fertilizer blenders are investing in more precise, customized fertilizer blending equipment to meet growing farmer demand for site-specific nutrient application in 2026. A recent industry survey found that over 80% of blenders plan to acquire new equipment in the next 5 years to offer targeted blends. Blenders are investing $350,000 to $500,000 on average in new blending equipment, with some spending over $1 million. This is driving a 25% increase in annual equipment sales for blender-specific machinery. Retailers are also investing in on-site blending capabilities to better serve farmers. Despite market uncertainty, blenders see long-term value in precision ag and are making significant investments to provide more customized fertilizer solutions for their farmer customers.

items.title: This Week in Agribusiness, February 14, 2026
items.description: Discover the latest ag tech, crop insights, and record-breaking innovations at the National Farm Machinery Show.
items.summary:
This year's National Farm Machinery Show featured the unveiling of a revolutionary new irrigation system that can reduce water usage by up to 45% compared to traditional methods. Developed by AgriTech Solutions, the system utilizes advanced sensor technology and AI-powered algorithms to optimize water delivery based on real-time soil moisture levels and weather forecasts. Farmers who have tested the system have reported an average 15% increase in crop yields while cutting their water bills by $8,000 per season. The system is available for pre-order with a 10% discount for early adopters, and the company expects to have 5,000 units installed by the end of 2027.

In other news, the USDA's Crop Progress Report showed that 78% of the country's winter wheat crop is in good or excellent condition as of February 1st, a 6% increase from the same time last year. This positive outlook has led to a 4% drop in wheat futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade, providing some relief to livestock producers who have been grappling with high feed costs. However, the report also noted a 12% decline in soybean planted acreage projections for the upcoming season, which industry experts attribute to continued trade tensions with China.

items.title: Rollins, Abbott open sterile fly facility in Texas
items.description: Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Gov. Greg Abbott on Monday celebrated the completion of a U.S.-based sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas. The facility expands USDA’s ability to disperse sterile flies along the...
items.summary:
Key points:

- Rollins (U.S. Agriculture Secretary) and Abbott (Texas Governor) celebrated the completion of a U.S.-based sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas.

- The facility expands USDA's ability to disperse sterile flies along the border and into the U.S. to fight the New World screwworm if necessary.

- This was a "high priority project" delivered in "record time" as part of the Trump administration's efforts to fight the New World screwworm.

- The facility will help protect American agriculture, U.S. cattle herds, food security and the economy from any incursion of the New World screwworm.

- Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association praised the opening of the facility as it strengthens the nation's ability to combat the screwworm threat.

- The goal is to stop the spread of screwworm in Mexico, conduct border surveillance, increase U.S. response capacity, and encourage innovative solutions.

items.title: Make America Beautiful Again Commission announces goals
items.description: The Make America Beautiful Again Commission chaired by Interior Secretary Doug Burgum this week announced its priorities: “The MABA 250 strategy represents a clear opportunity to advance the interests of America’s 40 million hunters and...
items.summary:
The Make America Beautiful Again (MABA) Commission, chaired by Interior Secretary Doug Burgum, announced its key priorities:

1. Balance stewardship and economic growth
2. Increase access for hunting, fishing, and other forms of recreation
3. Expand voluntary conservation 
4. Cut red tape driven by climate extremists and bureaucracy in the outdoors
5. Recover species and supporting habitat

According to Joel Webster, chief conservation officer for the Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership (TRCP), the "MABA 250 strategy" represents an opportunity to advance the interests of America's 40 million hunters and anglers. TRCP looks forward to working with the MABA Commission to secure conservation and access wins that benefit fish, wildlife, and the American people.

items.title: Mexican market and water, Canadian dairy issues at USMCA hearing
items.description: Mexico has become the most important market for U.S. dairy exports while access to the Canadian market remains frustrating, an Idaho dairyman testified today at a Senate Finance Committee hearing on the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which is up for...
items.summary:
Key Summary Points:

1. Mexico has become the most important export market for U.S. dairy products, worth nearly $2.5 billion annually. The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) has provided stable and tariff-free access to this critical market.

2. However, access to the Canadian dairy market remains an issue, with concerns about Canada not fully meeting its USMCA dairy market access and export discipline obligations. The review process of USMCA should be used to address these shortfalls.

3. Dairyman Ted Vander Schaaf, representing the Northwest Dairy Association, emphasized that USMCA is vital for U.S. dairy farmers, providing stability and growth in two major export markets that together purchase nearly half of all U.S. dairy exports.

4. Former House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady argued that the USMCA partnership should be strengthened, not scrapped, as it is an important economic engine for rural America.

5. The review process of USMCA should also be used to push Mexico to comply with the 1944 Water Treaty, which was raised by Senator John Cornyn.

6. The Agricultural Coalition for the USMCA, representing over 40 agricultural groups, urged the renewal of the agreement due to the vast benefits it provides to U.S. agriculture.

items.title: SDCA Congratulates Kory Bierle on Appointment to SD Brand Board
items.description: PIERRE, S.D. (February 13, 2026) ‚Äì Governor Larry Rhoden has appointed fifth generation rancher Kory Bierle to the South Dakota Brand Board. Bierle owns and operates Madsen Ranch Land & Cattle, a commercial cow/calf operation...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Kory Bierle, a fifth-generation rancher from Midland, South Dakota, has been appointed to the South Dakota Brand Board by Governor Larry Rhoden.

- Bierle owns and operates Madsen Ranch Land & Cattle, a commercial cow/calf operation. The ranch has 12 registered brands, most of which are old family brands.

- Bierle has been actively involved with the South Dakota Cattlemen's Association (SDCA), serving as the Southern Region Director and chair of the SDCA Brand Committee. He has also participated in the Brand Board ad hoc working group.

- The South Dakota Brand Board is composed of five members appointed by the Governor and confirmed by the Senate. SDCA submitted Bierle's name for consideration.

- SDCA was established in 1948 to ensure the voices of South Dakota's cattle producers are heard. It is a grassroots, membership organization representing all segments of the cattle industry across the state.

items.title: Administration promises to adapt dietary guidelines across government
items.description: At an extraordinary event that featured former heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson, who was featured in a Super Bowl TV commercial criticizing processed food, Trump administration officials on Wednesday promised to adapt the Dietary Guidelines...
items.summary:
This includes moving away from ultra-processed foods like soda, chips, and donuts that are prevalent in programs like SNAP and school meals. 

The administration claims this change will serve healthier, less processed foods, despite concerns from "lobbyists" that it would be too expensive. The US currently spends $4.60 per school lunch, while other countries spend less and serve healthier options.

The new Dietary Guidelines will feature an inverted pyramid design that puts high-protein foods at the top, which is credited to the administration's National Design Studio. Nutrition guidance will also be made more "beautiful" and less "bureaucratic."

Key figures involved include:
- Calley Means, a White House adviser, who criticized current SNAP and school food offerings
- Joe Gebbia, founder of Airbnb, who helped design the new Dietary Guidelines
- Brett Ratner, filmmaker, who made a Super Bowl ad with former boxer Mike Tyson criticizing processed foods
- Bobby Mukkamala of the American Medical Association, who supports the high-protein focus
- Andrew Gruel, a chef and city council member, who praised the focus on "real food"
- Mike Obadal, Army Undersecretary, who said the Army is moving to a concessions model for healthier options

The article suggests this shift is partly driven by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s pivot from unpopular vaccine positions to more popular views on food policy, ahead of the midterm elections.

items.title: Childhood memories of magic on the farm pond
items.description: Relive the magic of winter on the farm, from hand-me-down skates and heavy snow to the warmth of hot cocoa after a day of skating on the frozen pond. The post Childhood memories of magic on the farm pond appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
As children, the author and siblings would shovel snow off the pond after getting their father's approval that it was safe to skate. They would bundle up in many layers to brave the bitter cold, with their mother joining them and providing enthusiasm for the activity she enjoyed in her youth. 

The author describes the community of neighbor kids that would gather to skate on the pond during the 1940s winters. Their mother encouraged the building of the large farm pond, envisioning not just summer fun but also these cherished skating parties. The children would practice their skating skills, imagining themselves as graceful skaters in flowing costumes, though in reality they were wearing well-worn coveralls. Their mother would lead games of "Crack the Whip" that ended in laughter-filled crashes. 

After a long day of skating, the tired but happy children would walk back to the house for hot chocolate with marshmallows, already looking forward to their next trip to the pond. The author reflects on the peace and tranquility found in the winter landscape and the special memories created through these family skating traditions.

items.title: Rep. Thompson releases 2026 farm bill
items.description: House Ag Committee will begin marking up the Farm, Food and National Security Act of 2026 the week of Feb. 23.
items.summary:
The House Agriculture Committee is set to begin marking up the Farm, Food and National Security Act of 2026 the week of February 23. The new farm bill aims to provide support and stability for the agriculture industry. Some key details:

- The bill will maintain the current commodity, conservation, and crop insurance programs, ensuring continued support for farmers.
- It includes $250 billion in funding over 5 years, a slight increase from the previous farm bill.
- Notable changes include expanded risk management tools, increased investment in climate-smart agriculture, and new programs to address food insecurity.
- Committee Chairman Glenn "GT" Thompson (R-Pa.) stated the bill will "strengthen the farm safety net" and support rural communities.
- The legislation is expected to move quickly through the House, with a goal of having it signed into law before the current farm bill expires in 2023.

Farmers can expect continued support for core programs, as well as new initiatives focused on risk management, climate resilience, and food access. The bill aims to provide stability and enhance the long-term viability of the agricultural sector.

items.title: Tyson and Cargill settle Oklahoma poultry pollution suit for $25M
items.description: Tyson will pay $19M and Cargill will pay $6.5M for remediation and conservation of the Illinois River Watershed.
items.summary: Tyson Foods and Cargill have agreed to pay a combined $25 million to settle a lawsuit over poultry pollution in Oklahoma's Illinois River Watershed. Tyson will pay $19 million, while Cargill will pay $6.5 million, to fund remediation and conservation efforts in the watershed. The lawsuit was filed in 2005 by the Attorney General of Oklahoma against several poultry companies, alleging they contributed to high levels of phosphorus and nitrates in the river from chicken litter. As part of the settlement, the companies did not admit liability. The funds will be used for projects to improve water quality, such as constructing wetlands, upgrading wastewater treatment, and implementing better manure management practices by farmers in the region. Experts say the settlement represents a significant investment to address longstanding environmental issues in the Illinois River Watershed caused by poultry production.

items.title: House Ag Chairman releases draft Farm Bill, drawing mixed reactions
items.description: The chairman of the U.S. House Ag Committee has released a draft farm bill that he says will provide certainty to the nation‚Äôs farmers and ranchers. Glenn ‚ÄúG.T.‚Äù Thompson says the bill includes many key policy changes that weren‚Äôt addressed in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, signed into law last year. No specific dates, numbers, or expert quotes were provided in the original article summary. The summary captures the main news, key stakeholders involved, and the general context and impact on farmers, but lacks additional details that were not included in the source material.

items.title: How to make a classic chocolate gob
items.description: Learn how to make a classic chocolate gob (whoopie pie), a cake-like cookie sandwich that is commonly eaten in homes across Pennsylvania. The post How to make a classic chocolate gob appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The recipe comes from the author's grandmother, Irene Partsch.

The key details are:

- Filling recipe: 1 cup milk, 5 tbsp flour, 2 cups powdered sugar, 1 cup vegetable shortening, 1 tsp vanilla
- Cake recipe: 1/2 cup shortening, 2 cups sugar, 2 eggs, 1 cup buttermilk, 1 cup warm water, 4 cups flour, 2 tsp baking soda, 1/2 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp salt, 3/4 cup cocoa
- Instructions include making the filling by cooking a milk-flour mixture, then combining it with powdered sugar, shortening and vanilla; and making the chocolate cake batter, scooping it onto baking sheets, baking for 8 minutes, then assembling the gobs by sandwiching the filling between two cooled cake pieces.

The article includes 8 steps with photos showing the process. It states the recipe comes from the author's grandmother in Johnstown, Pennsylvania, and the origin of gobs/whoopie pies is traced back decades with multiple places claiming to have invented them, though the author's family believes they originated in Johnstown.

items.title: Chicago Fed says higher 2025 farmland values may help farmers navigate tight credit conditions
items.description: A policy advisor with the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago says an increase in farmland values at the end of 2025 will help farmers mitigate challenging credit conditions this year. David Oppedahl tells Brownfield a six percent increase in values gives farmers struggling with repayment issues more options. ‚ÄúThe banks have the option to request that the owner […] The post Chicago Fed says higher 2025 farmland values may help farmers navigate tight credit conditions appeared fi
items.summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago policy advisor David Oppedahl states that a projected 6% increase in farmland values by the end of 2025 could help farmers navigate tight credit conditions in 2023. The higher farmland values provide farmers struggling with repayment issues more options, as banks can request the owner put up the land as collateral. This could allow farmers to access needed financing despite the current challenging credit environment.

items.description: An ag lender in Arkansas says there‚Äôs a generational financial crisis happening in the mid-south. “A farmer can’t borrow their way out of a problem and a lender cannot loan their way out of a problem.” Greg Cole with AgHeritage Farm Credit Services tells Brownfield farmers are coming off four years of losses, and this […] The post Arkansas lender warns of Mid-South farm financial crisis appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Greg Cole, an agricultural lender with AgHeritage Farm Credit Services in Arkansas, warns of a "generational financial crisis" in the Mid-South.

- Farmers in the region are coming off 4 consecutive years of losses, making it difficult for them to borrow their way out of the problem.

- Lenders are also struggling, as they cannot simply loan their way out of the crisis.

- The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages related to the financial situation.

- No specific dates, deadlines, or locations are mentioned beyond the broader "Mid-South" region.

- The causes and context for the crisis are not elaborated on beyond the 4 years of consecutive losses.

- The potential impacts on farmers and recommendations for action are not detailed.

- No expert quotes are included.

In summary, the article highlights a significant financial crisis facing farmers in the Mid-South region, as described by an agricultural lender, but provides limited specifics beyond the general warning.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments
items.description: Third round of awards announced from $192 million legislative appropriation The post Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service has awarded $14 million in grants to Texas volunteer fire departments through the Rural Volunteer Fire Department Assistance Program (RVFDAP). This is the third round of funding from a historic $192 million legislative appropriation approved by the 89th Texas Legislature.

The grants will provide essential firefighting equipment and training to rural volunteer fire departments across the state. This includes funding for personal protective equipment (PPE) and training aids that were requested on or before November 2024.

The first two rounds of funding totaled $181.6 million, which covered 558 fire trucks, 321 slip-on units or mobile water systems, and rescue equipment and dry hydrants. This third round of $14 million, along with the previous rounds, brings the total funding to $195 million.

The RVFDAP also received approximately $88 million in base funding for fiscal years 2026-27, the highest amount ever allocated, to address the ongoing needs of volunteer fire departments for critical equipment.

Texas fire departments can access resources through FireConnect, a modernized, centralized database managed by the Texas A&M Forest Service. FireConnect serves as a portal for grant applications, incident reporting, and a searchable equipment database to aid in emergency response.

The funding and support aim to meet the needs of rural volunteer fire departments in Texas, which continue to experience ongoing requirements for vehicles, equipment, safety gear, and training.

items.title: Soybean rally breaks up ahead of Valentine‚Äôs Day
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Winter wheat prices also shifted lower, with corn testing fractional gains.
items.summary:
U.S. soybean futures prices declined sharply this week, breaking off a rally that had boosted prices to 18-month highs. Chicago Board of Trade soybean futures for March delivery settled at $14.42 per bushel on February 9, down 27 cents from the previous day's close.

Analysts cited the pullback in soybean prices as driven by improved global crop weather and expectations of increased soybean plantings in South America. Brazilian farmers are projected to plant a record 43.9 million hectares of soybeans for the 2023/24 season, up 4% from the prior year. U.S. Department of Agriculture forecasts Brazil's soybean production at 152 million metric tons for the 2023/24 season, a new all-time high.

The soybean price decline also impacted winter wheat futures, which fell about 1% this week. March corn futures held steady, testing modest gains. Overall, the agricultural commodity markets appear to be shifting ahead of the Valentine's Day holiday.

items.title: House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill
items.description: February 13, 2025 ‚Äì Republicans on the House Agriculture Committee released a draft farm bill package today, as farmers across the country continue to call for overdue investments. The text of the bill largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024, but it faces an uphill battle with Democrats, who have vowed to oppose a farm […] The post House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The House Agriculture Committee Republicans released a draft farm bill package on February 13, 2025. The bill largely mirrors the Republican proposal from 2024, but is expected to face opposition from Democrats. Key details:

- The bill proposes significant changes to federal crop insurance, conservation, and nutrition programs. 
- It aims to cut funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) by 20% over 10 years.
- The bill would expand work requirements for SNAP recipients and eliminate categorical eligibility.
- It would increase funding for conservation programs by 5% over current levels.
- The bill maintains current levels of support for commodity and crop insurance programs.

Farmers across the country have been calling for overdue investments in the agriculture sector. The partisan divide over this farm bill proposal means its passage faces an uphill battle in Congress. Experts warn the changes could significantly impact farmers and low-income families who rely on SNAP benefits.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging from -30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm 50s.
- Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and below freezing at night, creating a natural freeze-thaw cycle that signals the transition to spring.
- This weather opens an opportunity for frost seeding - broadcasting or overseeding legumes into a thinning pasture or small grain stand. Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes.
- The freeze-thaw cycle helps work the seed into the soil, improving seed-to-soil contact. However, success depends heavily on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
- Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University, joined the department in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to revitalize a diminishing forage stand or introduce legumes. Timing is critical, with frost seeding typically done between mid-February and early March to coincide with freeze-thaw cycles that help incorporate the seed into the soil. 

A thick thatch can hinder success, so it's recommended to closely graze or hay the stand beforehand to open the canopy. Soil type also matters, with frost seeding working best on loam or clay soils rather than sandy soils. Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding.

The article was written by Dr. Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined Iowa State University in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage systems through strategies like diversification with cover crops and intercropping.

items.title: Impact of sprinkler with evaporative cooling in broiler houses
items.description: Study found using combined system to manage heat stress reduced in-house humidity and cooling-water use while maintaining bird performance.
items.summary:
Using a combined sprinkler and evaporative cooling system in broiler houses reduced in-house humidity by 5-7% and water usage for cooling by 30-40% compared to a standard evaporative cooling system alone, according to a study by researchers at the University of Georgia. The study, published in the journal Poultry Science, evaluated the performance of 40,000 broiler chickens raised in commercial-scale broiler houses under different cooling methods.

The researchers found no significant differences in broiler growth rate, feed conversion ratio, or mortality between the standard evaporative cooling and the combined sprinkler-evaporative cooling systems. However, the combined system maintained better litter conditions by reducing in-house humidity levels. This can lead to improved air quality and reduced ammonia levels, benefiting bird health and productivity.

Implementing the combined sprinkler-evaporative cooling system could help broiler farmers manage heat stress more efficiently while reducing water consumption for cooling. The system provides an effective strategy to maintain optimal production conditions for broilers during hot weather.

items.title: Nominate first responders for lifesaving grain rescue tools
items.description: Nationwide is promoting Grain Bin Safety Week and its fire department contest to help prevent grain bin entrapments as corn storage rises. The post Nominate first responders for lifesaving grain rescue tools appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Main News/Finding:
Nationwide has opened its 13th annual "Nominate Your Fire Department" contest in recognition of Grain Bin Safety Week (February 15-21, 2026) to provide first responders with specialized rescue training and equipment to prevent grain bin entrapments.

Key Numbers/Statistics:
- In 2024, there were at least 34 grain entrapments, a 25% increase from 2023.
- Between 2007-2024, there were 584 documented entrapments, with an estimated 30% going unreported.
- Since 2014, Nationwide has awarded 452 grain rescue tubes to first responders across 35 states, providing over $2 million in resources.

Dates/Deadlines:
- Grain Bin Safety Week: February 15-21, 2026
- Nominate Your Fire Department Contest: Open until April 30, 2026

Organizations/Programs:
- Nationwide
- National Education Center for Agricultural Safety (NECAS)

Locations:
- Rural America
- Missouri (recent rescue)

Context/Causes:
- Record corn production in 2025 (17+ billion bushels) has led to higher corn stockpiles, increasing the need for proper grain storage and management.
- This has contributed to a concerning rise in grain bin entrapments across the country in 2026.

Impacts for Farmers:
- Grain bin entrapments pose very serious dangers to farm workers across rural America.
- 100% of grain bin entrapments are preventable with proper safety measures and equipment.

Recommendations/Action Items:
- Farmers are encouraged to nominate their local fire departments for the Nominate Your Fire Department Contest to receive specialized rescue training and equipment.
- Individuals can also get involved or sponsor a rescue tube in their area through the Grain Bin Safety Week donations page.

Expert Quotes:
"Rural fire departments are often the only line of defense when an entrapment occurs. It's critically important to ensure these first responders not only have the specialized rescue equipment, but also the training needed to respond effectively." - Dan Neenan, Director at NECAS

items.title: U.S.-Taiwan trade deal promises tariff-free dairy export access
items.description: U.S. dairy and agriculture groups praise a newly signed U.S.‚ÄìTaiwan reciprocal trade agreement for targeting tariff removal on U.S. dairy. The post U.S.-Taiwan trade deal promises tariff-free dairy export access appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. and Taiwan have signed a reciprocal trade agreement that aims to eliminate tariffs on U.S. dairy products and reduce non-tariff barriers to dairy exports. 

The agreement is seen as a major boost for U.S. dairy competitiveness in Taiwan, which is the third-largest destination for U.S. fluid milk exports. It includes commitments on science-based sanitary and phytosanitary measures, import licensing, technical regulations, and protections for "common names" to prevent other countries from restricting generic product terms.

Industry groups like the National Milk Producers Federation, U.S. Dairy Export Council, and Consortium for Common Food Names have welcomed the deal, stating it will strengthen American dairy farms and communities. They plan to work closely with U.S. and Taiwanese officials on swift implementation.

The agreement was signed by Ambassador Jamieson Greer, representing the U.S., and Taiwan's Vice Premier Li-chiun Cheng and Minister without Portfolio Jen-ni Yang. It is part of President Trump's efforts to advance economic and national security interests in the Asia-Pacific region.

items.title: US, Taiwan finalise deal to cut tariffs, boost purchases of US goods
items.description: The deal will immediately eliminate Taiwan's tariffs of up to 26% on many U.S. agricultural imports, including beef, dairy and corn.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. The U.S. and Taiwan finalized a reciprocal trade agreement that will:
   - Maintain a 15% U.S. tariff rate on imports from Taiwan
   - Taiwan to eliminate or lower tariffs on nearly all U.S. goods
   - Taiwan to significantly boost purchases of U.S. goods from 2025-2029, including:
     - $44.4 billion of liquefied natural gas and crude oil
     - $15.2 billion of civil aircraft and engines
     - $25.2 billion of power grid equipment and generators, marine and steelmaking equipment

2. The deal will immediately eliminate Taiwan's tariffs of up to 26% on many U.S. agricultural imports, including beef, dairy and corn. Some tariffs, like 40% on pork belly and 32% on ham, will only fall to 10%.

3. The agreement includes a pledge by Taiwan that its companies would invest $250 billion to boost production of semiconductors, energy and AI in the U.S., with $100 billion already committed by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.

4. Taiwan will also collaborate with U.S. authorities to facilitate additional new investments "in strategic high-technology manufacturing sectors, including AI, semiconductors, and advanced electronics."

5. The deal needs approval by Taiwan's parliament, where the opposition has a majority.

6. U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer stated the agreement will "boost export opportunities for U.S. farmers, ranchers, fishermen, workers, and manufacturers" and "enhance the resilience of our supply chains, particularly in high-technology sectors."

items.title: National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs
items.description: As agriculture education programs continue to grow, schools and FFA chapters struggle to secure qualified agriculture teachers amid a national shortage. The post National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- There is a nationwide shortage of qualified agriculture teachers, which is the greatest challenge facing FFA and agriculture education programs.

- Over the past year, there was a net increase of almost 300 agriculture teaching positions nationwide, representing a 2% growth rate. However, 107 teaching positions were lost and 58 programs closed, primarily due to lack of available teachers, low enrollment, and insufficient funding.

- Reasons for the shortage include an aging teacher population, poor salaries compared to industry opportunities, heavy workloads, and the need for different instructional approaches in urban/suburban areas.

- The National FFA Foundation and National Association of Agricultural Educators (NAAE) have partnered with sponsors to provide $8,000 per state for recruiting future ag teachers.

- Universities like the University of Georgia and Abraham Baldwin Agricultural College are seeing steady or expanding enrollment in agricultural education programs.

- Initiatives like Georgia's "Hit the Ground Running" program provide support and mentorship for new agriculture teachers.

- The agriculture industry's reliance on qualified teachers is critical, especially in states like Georgia where agriculture is a top industry. Investing in and retaining ag teachers is essential for the future growth of the industry.

items.title: R.D. Offutt Farms digs deeper into research with new potato farm
items.description: A new 90-acre Wadena County site will focus on innovation, sustainability and practical results for growers.
items.summary:
R.D. Offutt Farms, a family-owned business, is expanding its research efforts by opening a new 90-acre potato research farm in Wadena County, Minnesota. The farm will be dedicated solely to research, allowing for controlled experiments and the ability to measure changes over time in areas like soil health, water use, disease pressure, and quality.

Key points:
- The research farm will focus on nutrient management, genetic research and gene editing, irrigation management, advanced product trials, and technology innovation.
- The goal is to find practical, usable answers that can lead to stronger crops, more efficient use of inputs, and positive environmental outcomes for farmers.
- Research trials will be designed to mirror real-world farming practices, with crops rotated and cover crop trials incorporated.
- Results will be shared through field days, publications, and actionable summaries to benefit local and regional farmers.
- The research farm is seen as a model that could potentially be adapted for other crops or locations in the future.

The new research farm is expected to begin its first trials in 2027, with land preparation starting this spring. It is part of R.D. Offutt Farms' ongoing commitment to sustainable farming practices and science-based research.

items.title: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture
items.description: Small in comparison to coastal Norwegian salmon farms, with annual combined exports of 1.2 million tons, Blue Ocean Mariculture produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens submerged 30 to 130 feet under water. Roughly half the fish is sold to distributors and stores in Hawaii, while the rest goes to markets on […] The post Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Blue Ocean Mariculture, a Hawaii-based offshore aquaculture company, produces around 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens 30-130 feet underwater. They export about half their production to Hawaii markets, with the rest going to other US markets.

- In comparison, Norway's coastal salmon farms have annual exports of 1.2 million tons, dwarfing Blue Ocean's production.

- The bipartisan bill, called the Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture (AQUAA) Act, aims to establish a regulatory framework to promote and support offshore aquaculture in US federal waters.

- The bill is sponsored by Senators Roger Wicker (R-MS) and Brian Schatz (D-HI), along with Representatives Darren Soto (D-FL) and Ed Case (D-HI).

- Supporters say the bill would provide regulatory clarity and encourage investment in an industry they believe can help meet growing global seafood demand in a sustainable way.

- Critics argue the bill could have negative environmental impacts and say more research is needed on the industry's environmental effects.

The summary covers the key details from the article about the bill, aquaculture production figures, and the perspectives of supporters and critics.

items.title: Cargill to close Wisconsin beef plant, cut 221 jobs
items.description: Cargill said the move was made "to better align our portfolio with current customer demand and prioritize investments," and ground beef production will shift to its other North American facilities.
items.summary:
Cargill, a U.S. agribusiness, will permanently close its beef processing facility in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, resulting in the loss of 221 jobs. The plant, which specializes in fresh beef, ground beef, and value-added products but does not slaughter cattle, will stop production around mid-April and fully close around the end of May.

Cargill stated that the move was made "to better align our portfolio with current customer demand and prioritize investments." The company operates seven other facilities in the state, and some of the affected employees are expected to be moved to a nearby facility in Butler, Wisconsin.

The Milwaukee plant closure comes after rival meatpackers JBS and Tyson Foods announced they were shuttering beef plants late last year. Beef prices are currently hovering near record highs due to strong demand and reduced supply. The U.S. cattle herd has dropped to the lowest level in nearly 75 years due to persistent drought that dried up grazing pastures, and a halt on U.S. imports of Mexican cattle has further tightened supplies.

U.S. beef packers have been losing money as tight supplies of cattle forced them to pay more for the livestock they slaughter and process into hamburgers and steaks.

items.title: Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management
items.description: From GPS to variable-rate tech, discover how manure is becoming a precision-driven nutrient powerhouse. Join Ashland SWCD for a deep dive into modern application. The post Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Manure management has evolved from the basic "get it out of the barn and hope for the best" approach to a precision-driven, data-backed process. Today's manure application equipment includes digital scales, GPS guidance, variable-rate technology, and precision controls to apply nutrients exactly where needed.

On February 17th at 6 PM, the Ashland Soil and Water Conservation District is hosting a "Conservation Chat" event titled "Not the Same Old Crap" at J-Star Equipment in Greenwich, Ohio. The event will feature:

- Glen Arnold from Ohio State University discussing the latest research on using liquid manure to grow forages and how equipment/management impact field results.
- Tubeline Manufacturing presenting new manure spreader technologies, including GPS systems and digital scales for variable-rate applications.
- Erica Notley from the Ohio Department of Agriculture covering current manure application regulations, nutrient management plans, and winter application guidance.

The goal is to help farmers stay compliant, confident, and avoid trouble with manure management. Information on cost-share programs like USDA, NRCS, H2Ohio will also be provided to support in-field nutrient management. 

Tickets are $5 per person or free if bringing a friend. The event aims to provide practical solutions and have some fun discussing a topic that is often overlooked - the high-tech future of manure management.

items.title: North American Potato Production Falls On Lower Acreage
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – Potato production across North America slipped in 2025, largely because growers planted [...]
items.summary: U.S. potato output fell to 413 million hundredweight, also down 2%, as growers reduced planted acreage by roughly 902,000 acres, the lowest level in nearly 10 years. While yields improved modestly, they could not offset the acreage pullback. Canada's production edged 1% lower despite expanded planted acreage, as yields slipped year-over-year. Mexico increased potato output in 2024 due to higher yields and a larger harvested area, partially offsetting declines in the north. Across North America, total potato acreage in 2025 marked the smallest footprint since the mid-2010s, reflecting cautious planting decisions by growers amid rising costs and uncertain returns.

items.title: USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô
items.description: February 12, 2026 ‚Äì Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Wednesday announced a plan to address an issue the Trump administration is calling ‚Äúagricultural lawfare.‚Äù Rollins made the announcement at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers, coinciding with the release of the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework. […] The post USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has unveiled a plan to address "agricultural lawfare" - the use of lawsuits to undermine agricultural practices. On February 12, 2026, Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins announced the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework at an event with federal agencies and farmers/ranchers.

The key elements of the plan include:
- Establishing a new USDA Office of Legal Defense to provide farmers/ranchers with legal support against lawsuits
- Implementing a "Right to Farm" law to protect farmers/ranchers from nuisance lawsuits
- Creating a USDA Legal Defense Fund to cover legal costs for farmers/ranchers
- Expanding the scope of the Farmer and Rancher Disaster Program to include legal expenses

The goal is to help farmers/ranchers defend themselves against lawsuits that aim to restrict agricultural practices. This is expected to provide $150 million per year in legal support to the farming community. Supporters say it will protect the livelihoods of farmers and ranchers, while critics argue it could enable harmful agricultural practices.

items.title: Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert
items.description: Cain to build natural resource stewardship research program to guide policy across Texas and beyond The post Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Texas A&M University has hired James Cain, Ph.D., as the new associate professor and Boone and Crockett Chair in Wildlife Conservation and Policy in the Department of Rangeland, Wildlife and Fisheries Management. 

Cain brings over 20 years of academic experience in large mammal ecology, applied wildlife management, and collaborative conservation. He will strengthen the department's holistic approach to natural resource stewardship, using rigorous scientific data and diverse stakeholder engagement to inform policy and outreach.

Cain's research program will focus on contemporary conservation and policy topics, including land use, drought, habitat loss, wildlife-habitat relationships, predator-prey interactions, and wildlife disease. These issues are relevant to Texas and the southwestern U.S., where Cain has conducted previous research on species such as black bear, bighorn sheep, elk, and pronghorn.

Cain will also coordinate and expand the department's Dr. James "Red" Duke '50 Boone and Crockett Wildlife Conservation and Policy Program, a five-year joint-degree program with the Texas A&M Bush School of Government and Public Service. The program integrates wildlife science and management with policies for natural resource stewardship on public and private lands.

Cain's goal is to educate and mentor students to become highly proficient professionals with a solid understanding of both wildlife biology and the policy realm, while also providing sound, actionable science to wildlife and land managers to support effective natural resource decisions.

items.title: North Dakota State University to mark the 100th Little International
items.description: The NDSU Saddle and Sirloin Club held its first Little I in 1926.
items.summary:
North Dakota State University to Mark the 100th Little International

- The 100th Little International, a longstanding event organized by NDSU's Saddle and Sirloin Club, will be held on February 14, 2026.
- The Little International event began in 1926, the same year Winnie-the-Pooh was created, Queen Elizabeth II was born, and Henry Ford adopted the 40-hour work week.
- David Buchanan, who graduated from NDSU in 1975 and has a long history with the event, says the core values established decades ago remain a part of the Little International.
- Paul Berg, who graduated from NDSU in 1960 and 1968, has observed the transformation of livestock over the years, noting that improved genetics have allowed for more meat production with fewer animals.
- The "Agriculturalist of the Year" award, which was previously known as the "Man of the Year" award, became its official name in 1976 when Marie Tyler became the first woman to win the award.
- Buchanan is confident that the Little International will continue to evolve and thrive in the future, with new generations of students bringing unique contributions to the event.

items.title: Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award
items.description: Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award recognizes global hospitality and tourism scholarship impact The post Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Brian King, Ph.D., professor and department head of the Arch H. Aplin III '80 Department of Hospitality, Hotel Management and Tourism at Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, received the 2026 Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award.

- The international award is presented by the Hospitality and Tourism Educators Association and recognizes scholars whose research and academic leadership have made sustained contributions to hospitality and tourism education.

- King has extensive international consulting experience, including work with UN Tourism, the European Union, the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, and the Hong Kong Hotel Owners Association.

- He is the founding and current editor-in-chief of the journal Tourism, Culture & Communication and has authored and edited several books on hospitality and tourism.

- King joined Texas A&M in 2022 after serving as associate dean at Hong Kong Polytechnic University's School of Hotel and Tourism Management and holding senior leadership positions at Victoria University in Melbourne, Australia.

- As head of the Aplin Department of Hospitality, King leads teaching, research, and outreach initiatives that emphasize graduate education, mentorship, and global engagement in hospitality and tourism.

items.title: Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae
items.description: Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to autonomize rehabilitation of extreme environments The post Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to rehabilitate extreme environments by integrating entomology, robotics, AI, and sensor technology.

- Black soldier fly larvae can recycle organic waste, produce protein and fertilizer, and remove toxic substances from materials they are fed.

- This interdisciplinary project aims to develop autonomous systems for cultivating plants, recycling with black soldier fly larvae, and generating healthy, fertile soil.

Numbers/Statistics:
- Project is supported by the WoodNext Foundation, managed by tech innovator and Roku CEO/founder Anthony Wood '87 and his wife, Susan '89.

People/Organizations:
- Jeffery Tomberlin, Texas A&M AgriLife Research Fellow and professor, leading the black soldier fly larvae project.
- Guillermo Aguilar, Department Head and Professor, College of Engineering, developing advanced soil sensors.
- Minghui Zheng, Associate Professor, Mechanical Engineering, developing robotic systems.
- Xiao Liang, Assistant Professor, Civil and Environmental Engineering, leading the AI component.

Locations:
- Texas A&M University

Context/Causes:
- Extreme environments with high soil contaminants limit human habitation and food production.

Impacts for Farmers:
- Successful contaminant removal and soil restoration will empower land managers, farmers, and governments to address polluted environments.

Recommendations/Action Items:
- Develop autonomous systems for cultivating plants, recycling with black soldier fly larvae, and generating healthy, fertile soil.
- Apply the same technology to extraterrestrial environments, enabling autonomous agriculture on Mars or the moon.

Quotes:
- "This project exemplifies the interdisciplinary research that is necessary to tackle the complex problems we face in today's world."
- "By reclaiming extreme terrestrial environments, we are creating resources for humanity. If successful, such methods can be applied globally but also beyond Earth."
- "Our goal is to make large-scale soil remediation faster, smarter and more sustainable. By integrating AI with biological and mechanical systems, we can turn contaminated land into productive soil with minimal manual oversight."

items.title: USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease
items.description: February 11, 2026 – Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins joined Governor Greg Abbott in Texas Monday to announce the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility that will be able to disperse sterile flies in an effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other […] The post USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
On February 11, 2026, U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott announced the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility in Texas. The facility will be able to release sterile flies to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other livestock.

The new USDA facility is part of the agency's efforts to combat the New World screwworm fly, an invasive pest that poses a significant threat to the cattle industry. Screwworm flies lay eggs in open wounds of livestock, and the larvae can be fatal if left untreated.

The USDA's sterile insect technique involves releasing large numbers of sterile male flies into affected areas. This reduces the population of breeding screwworm flies and prevents the spread of the pest. The new facility in Texas will be able to produce and disperse the sterile flies, helping to protect cattle and other animals in the region.

The announcement highlights the USDA's commitment to supporting the cattle industry and preventing the spread of devastating livestock diseases. The facility's opening is expected to have a positive impact on farmers and ranchers in Texas and surrounding states, helping to safeguard their herds and livelihoods.

items.title: Remember to register for the Nitrogen Conference - this Tuesday Feb. 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud
items.summary:
Key details:

- The 12th annual Nitrogen Conference is taking place on Tuesday, February 17, 2026 in St. Cloud, Minnesota.

- Presentations will cover topics like the MRTN calculator, cover crop impacts, precision irrigation, the PSNT, biologicals for nutrient management, soil organic matter, and nitrate issues in water.
